4vr.title: Subjective probability
4vr.clickbait: Probability is in the mind, not in the environment.  If you don't know whether a coin came up heads or tails, that's a fact about you, not a fact about the coin.
4vr.text:
[summary:  What does it *mean* to say that a fair coin has a 50% probability of landing heads?

On the subjectivist view, statements of probability are ways of quantifying our own uncertainty.  If I flip a coin and slap it onto my wrist, it's already landed either heads or tails.  The fact that I don't know whether the coin has landed heads or tails is a fact about me, not a fact about the coin.  Ignorance is [4yk in the mind, not in reality]; a blank map does not correspond to a blank territory.  To reason rigorously about this subjective uncertainty, we use [1bv probability theory].

Subjectivism stands in contrast to *frequentism*, a developed discipline of statistics which tries to establish objective correspondences between frequency-statements and classes of events.  Subjectivism also stands in contrast to an intuitive feeling that the coin's probability of landing heads is a fact about the coin, rather than a way of quantifying our own ignorance, which in philosophical discussion is the *propensity* view of probability.]

What does it *mean* to say that a flipped coin has a 50% probability of landing heads?

Historically, there have been two main answers to this question, the "frequentist" versus the "subjective" or "[1r8 Bayesian]" answer.  These two answers have given rise to [4xx two entirely different approaches to experimental statistics].

- **Frequentism:**  There's a *class* of events similar to this coinflip.  This class could be "all the times we flip this coin", or "all the times we flip coins similar to this one".  Across this class, the coin comes up heads half the time; that is, the *frequency* of the coin coming up heads is 50% inside this class.  When we state this, we are asserting a definite fact about the event class.
- **Subjectivism:**   Uncertainty is in the mind, not in the environment.  If I flip a coin and slap it onto my wrist, it's already landed either heads or tails.  The fact that I don't know whether the coin has landed heads or tails is a fact about me, not a fact about the coin.  The way I *express my own ignorance* is by saying that I'd bet at 1 : 1 odds that the coin came up heads.

There's also a third view:

- **Propensities:**  There's a kind of probability that's directly out there in the world.  When we flip a coin, this single event has a *propensity* of 0.50 for the coin to show heads.  When we say the coin has a 50% probability of being heads, we're talking directly about this propensity.

The propensity view seems difficult to reconcile with the idea that once we've flipped the coin, it has already landed heads or tails.  But it may in a sense be the most *intuitive* view, because of the [4yk Mind Projection Fallacy]:  We think in cognitively basic mental probabilities, so we find it very easy to imagine a *world* that contains ontologically basic uncertainty.

# Map-territory correspondence links

We can see the different views as corresponding to different theories of truth, or accuracy, when it comes to evaluating the relationship between a probabilistic map, and the territory.

In non-probabilistic maps and territories, [the notion of 'truth' is comparatively straightforward](http://www.yudkowsky.net/rational/the-simple-truth/): [to say of what is, that it is](http://classicalwisdom.com/greek_books/metaphysics-by-aristotle-book-iv/7/), and of what is not, that it is not, is true.

![ordinary truth](http://i.imgur.com/1Zl9l3R.jpg?4)

But how do you draw a correspondence link between a probabilistic map and a territory?  If you think a biased coin has a 70% probability of coming up heads, how do you draw a correspondence link between *that* and the territory?  If the coin is actually heads, is the map true?  Or 70% true?  Or what?

![probability truth?](http://i.imgur.com/aiDr7Tu.jpg?2)

----------

The **propensity** view is the most straightforward:  [4yk The territory has just the same ontology as the map.]  If your probability matches the propensity, the map is *true*; if it doesn't, the map is false.

![propensity correspondence](http://i.imgur.com/lmFCwV2.jpg?3)

----------

A **subjectivist** imagines multiple probable worlds in the map, and draws a correspondence line between that probability distribution and a single territory.

The more probability the map assigns to the correct answer, the better the map.  If everywhere the map says "30% probability it's like X", the territory is that way around 30% of the time, the subjectivist calls that a well-calibrated map.

![bayesian correspondence](http://i.imgur.com/qQIyVsb.jpg?2)

But there's no uncertainties *actually* out there in the territory; ignorance is a property of minds, not environments; blank sections of a map don't correspond to places where the world itself goes blank.

----------

A **frequentist** draws a line between a single probability-statement in the map, and multiple events in the territory.  If the map says "30%" about an outcome in a class, and the actual territory contains 30% outcomes like that in the corresponding class, the frequentist says the map is *factually true.*  The correspondence link is direct: the map makes a statement, and the world *is* like that.

![frequentist correspondence](http://i.imgur.com/eKH3ReW.jpg?4)

Frequentists see only this kind of actually-true statement as possibly being objective - under the subjectivist kind of correspondence, who can tell whether the map ought to say 70% or 75%, since it's not clearly 'true' or 'false' either way?  Therefore, scientific reports ought to be restricted to frequentist statements that can be definitely true or false, in order to increase the objectivity of science.

# Examples

Scenarios that showcase the divide between the views of probability:

## Betting on one-time events

Consider evaluating, in e.g. June of 2016, the question:  "What is the probability of Hillary Clinton winning the 2016 US presidential election?"

On the **propensity** view, Hillary has some chance of winning the election.  To ask about the probability is to ask about this objective chance.  If we see a prediction market in which prices move after each new poll - so that it says 60% one day, and 80% a week later - then clearly the prediction market isn't giving us very strong information about this objective chance, since it doesn't seem very likely that Clinton's *real* chance of winning is swinging so rapidly.  Similarly, when Brexit prediction markets assigned a 13% chance of Brexit a day before the event, they were clearly vastly underestimating the real propensity of Britain to secede from the European Union.

On the **subjective** view, saying that Hillary has an 80% chance of winning the election summarizes our *knowledge about* the election or our *state of uncertainty.*  It makes sense for the prediction market prices to change in response to new polls, because our current state of knowledge is changing.  If when prediction markets say 60%, the corresponding event happens around 6 times out of 10, that's a well-calibrated prediction market.  If nobody in the world knows any better, nobody can exploit the prediction market to systematically make money.  When prediction markets say 13%, the corresponding event needs to happen *sometimes* (like 2 in 15 times) because if it didn't, the prediction market would be underconfident and you could systematically make money by selling the long-shots.

On the **frequentist** view, we cannot formally or rigorously say anything about the 2016 presidential election, because it only happens once.  We can't *observe* a frequency with which Clinton wins presidential elections.  A non-straw frequentist might concede that they would, indeed, cheerfully buy for \$1 a ticket that pays \$20 if Clinton wins, considering this an extremely favorable bet... in an *informal* sense, using a kind of reasoning that isn't based in rigorous epistemology, and might not be all that coherent, and certainly isn't suitable for being included in science journals.

## A coin with an unknown bias

Suppose we have a coin, weighted so that it lands heads somewhere between 0% and 100% of the time, but we don't know the coin's actual bias.

The coin is then flipped three times where we can see it.  It comes up heads twice, and tails once:  HHT.

The coin is then flipped again, where nobody can see it yet.  An honest and trustworthy experimenter lets you spin a wheel-of-gambling-odds, and the wheel lands on (2 : 1).  The experiment asks if you'd enter into a gamble where you win \$2 if the unseen coinflip is tails, and pay \$1 if the unseen coinflip is heads.

(The reason for spinning the wheel-of-gambling-odds is to reduce the worry that the experimenter might know more about the coin than you, and be offering you a deliberately rigged bet.)

On a **propensity** view, the coin has some objective probability between 0 and 1 of being heads, but we don't know this probability.  Seeing HHT tells us that the coin isn't all-heads or all-tails, but we're still just guessing what the real propensity is - we don't really know the answer.

On a **frequentist** view, the coin would produce some long-run frequency $f$ of heads that is between 0 and 1.  In other words, if we keep flipping the coin long enough, the actual proportion $p$ of observed heads is guaranteed to approach $f$ arbitrarily closely, eventually.  This is a true statement about the class of events where we continue to flip the coin - we can't say that the *next* coinflip is guaranteed to be H or T, but we can make a true statement about $p$ approaching $f$ to within epsilon if we continue to flip the coin long enough.

So what does a frequentist do with the data HHT?  A frequentist might try to apply an "unbiased estimator" to the data we have so far.  An "unbiased estimator" is a rule for making an estimate $e$ of $f$ based on observations, such that if we start by thinking about the true value of $f,$ applying this rule to data randomly generated from $f,$ produces an estimate $e$ whose expectation is $f.$  In other words, a frequentist wants a rule such that, if the hidden bias of the coin was in fact to yield 75% heads, and we repeat many times the operation of flipping the coin a few times and then asking a new frequentist to estimate the coin's bias using this rule, the *average* value of the estimated bias will be 0.75.  This is a true and rigorous statement about the estimation rule.  We can't hope for a rule that will always, in any particular case, yield the true $f$ from just a few coinflips; but we can have a rule of which we can rigorously say that the *average* estimate it yields, if we repeat this experiment many times, is $f.$

In this case, a simple unbiased estimator is to guess that the coin's bias $f$ is equal to the observed proportion $p$ of heads, or 2/3.  This means that a bet of \$2 vs. $\1 is fair, meaning that it doesn't yield an expected profit, so we have no reason to take the bet.

On a **Bayesian** view, we start out psychologically unsure of where the bias $f$ lies within the interval [0, 1].  Unless we have any knowledge or suspicion leading us to think otherwise, the coin is equally liable to have a bias between 31% and 32%, as to have a bias between 60% and 61%.

Each coinflip we see is then [22x evidence] about the value of $f,$ since a flip H happens with different probabilities depending on the different values of $f,$ and we update our beliefs about $f$ using [1lz Bayes's Rule].

E.g., we start out thinking the coin is equally likely to have a bias in the range $[\frac{1}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{1}{3} + \epsilon]$ as in $[\frac{2}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{2}{3} + \epsilon].$  We then observe one coinflip which comes up H.  Seeing H is twice is likely if $f=\frac{2}{3}$ than if $f=\frac{1}{3}$ so by [1zm Bayes's Rule] we should now think $f$ is twice as likely to lie in the interval $[\frac{2}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{2}{3} + \epsilon]$ as in $[\frac{1}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{1}{3} + \epsilon]$.

When we start with a uniform [219 prior], observe multiple flips of a coin with an unknown bias, see M heads and N tails, and then try to estimate the odds of the next flip coming up heads, the result is [21c Laplace's Rule of Succession] which estimates (M + 1) : (N + 1) or a probability of $\frac{M + 1}{M + N + 2}.$

In this case, after observing HHT, we estimate odds of 2/5 vs. 3/5 for tails vs. heads on the next flip.  This makes a gamble that wins \$2 on tails and loses \$1 on heads a profitable gamble in expectation, so we take the bet.

Our choice of a [219 uniform prior] over $f$ was *somewhat* shaky - it expressed ignorance in an obvious way, but obviousness isn't everything.  However, all the reasoning we did past that point was rigorous and based on [1bv probability theory], which various [coherence_theorems coherence theorems] prove to be the only way of manipulating quantified uncertainty that obeys obvious-seeming rules about how subjective uncertainty should behave.  Given our starting beliefs and quantified uncertainties, the remaining reasoning steps we carried out were *valid,* the way that $((X \rightarrow Y) \wedge (Y \rightarrow Z))\rightarrow(X \rightarrow Z)$ is valid reasoning in propositional logic.  [4xx There's no reason not to include this kind of reasoning in a science paper.]

## Probability that the 98,765th decimal digit of $\pi$ is $0$.

The **propensity** and **frequentist** views regard as nonsense the notion that we could talk about the *probability* of a mathematical fact.  Either the 98,765th decimal digit of $\pi$ is $0$ or it's not.  If we're running *repeated* experiments with a random number generator, then it might make sense to say that the random number generator has a 1\10 probability of picking numbers whose corresponding decimal digit of $\pi$ is $0$.  But if we're just picking a non-random number like 98,765, there's no sense in which we could say that the 98,765th digit of $\pi$ has a 10% propensity to be $0$, or that this digit is $0$ with 10% frequency in the long run.

The **subjectivist** considers probabilities to just refer to their own uncertainty.  So if a Bayesian has picked the number 98,765 without yet knowing the corresponding digit of $\pi,$ and hasn't made any observation that is known to them to be entangled with the 98,765th digit of $\pi,$ and they're pretty sure their friend hasn't yet looked up the 98,765th digit of $\pi$ either, and their friend offers a whimsical gamble that costs \$1 if the digit is $1-9$ and pays \$20 if the digit is $0,$ the Bayesian takes the bet.

*(Note:  You should no longer take this exact bet because somebody is going to look it up after reading this node, and if they offer you that exact bet, it might be because the number they looked up was not $0$.  Pick a different digit of $\pi$ instead.)*

# Generality of subjectivism

Subjective probabilities embrace all frequentist and propensity-based statements as special cases.

If it's a fact about a coin-flipping machine that its physical symmetries are such as to produce 50% heads in a way that's impossible for us to predict in any greater detail, then all the valid reasoning steps within the propensity view of probability will also be valid reasoning steps within the subjectivist view of probability.  E.g. a subjectivist agrees that if you roll two standard six-sided dice and add the results, the subjective probability of seeing 7 is 1/6.

Similarly, a Bayesian will agree that the estimation rule M/(M+N) for the probability $p$ of the next coin being heads, based on seeing M heads and N tails, has the property that its expected estimate equals the true frequency... or rather, the Bayesian thinks this in advance of actually running the experiment.  As soon as the coin actually comes up HHT, the Bayesian thinks that 2/3 is not actually a good estimate of the chance that the next coin will be heads.  In other words, the Bayesian disagrees that the 'unbiased estimator' property means you get reasonable answers when you actually run the rule on any particular occasion.  But the Bayesian does agree that the 'unbiased estimator' property being asserted, is subjectively valid, given their current uncertainty about the coin and the future experimental results.

# Arguments

As near as the author of this node can figure, the philosophical case *against* subjectivism (or *for* frequentism or propensity-based views) rests on a charge of epistemological sloppiness, with the implication that some other view of probability is more firmly grounded.  The Bayesian reply is something along the lines of "Mathematically rigorous probability theory!  Coherence theorems showing this theory is unique!  We're continuing to improve the theory of priors, and if you don't implicitly assume something along the lines of 'induction works' then your own reasoning wouldn't work either.  And your alternative view of probability [4xx leads to weird practices] because of arbitrarily excluding perfectly valid lines of reasoning."

For more, see [4xx here] or the [SEP entry on interpretations of probability](http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/probability-interpret/).

7ry.title: Coherence theorems
7ry.clickbait: A 'coherence theorem' shows that something bad happens to an agent if its decisions can't be viewed as 'coherent' in some sense. E.g., an inconsistent preference ordering leads to going in circles.

4vr.clickbait: Probability is in the mind, not in the environment.  If you don't know whether a coin came up heads or tails, that's a fact about you, not a fact about the coin.

[summary:  What does it *mean* to say that a fair coin has a 50% probability of landing heads?

The fact that I don't know whether the coin has landed heads or tails is a fact about me, not a fact about the coin. In non-probabilistic maps and territories, [the notion of 'truth' is comparatively straightforward](http://www.yudkowsky.net/rational/the-simple-truth/): [to say of what is, that it is](http://classicalwisdom.com/greek_books/metaphysics-by-aristotle-book-iv/7/), and of what is not, that it is not, is true.

![ordinary truth](http://i.imgur.com/1Zl9l3R.jpg?4)

If you think a biased coin has a 70% probability of coming up heads, how do you draw a correspondence link between *that* and the territory?  If the coin is actually heads, is the map true? ![probability truth?](http://i.imgur.com/aiDr7Tu.jpg?2)

The **propensity** view is the most straightforward:  [4yk The territory has just the same ontology as the map.]  If your probability matches the propensity, the map is *true*; if it doesn't, the map is false.

![propensity correspondence](http://i.imgur.com/lmFCwV2.jpg?3)

![bayesian correspondence](http://i.imgur.com/qQIyVsb.jpg?2)

But there's no uncertainties *actually* out there in the territory; ignorance is a property of minds, not environments; blank sections of a map don't correspond to places where the world itself goes blank.

Therefore, scientific reports ought to be restricted to frequentist statements that can be definitely true or false, in order to increase the objectivity of science.

# Examples

Scenarios that showcase the divide between the views of probability:

## Betting on one-time events

Consider evaluating, in e.g. June of 2016, the question:  "What is the probability of Hillary Clinton winning the 2016 US presidential election?"

On the **propensity** view, Hillary has some chance of winning the election.  To ask about the probability is to ask about this objective chance.  If we see a prediction market in which prices move after each new poll - so that it says 60% one day, and 80% a week later - then clearly the prediction market isn't giving us very strong information about this objective chance, since it doesn't seem very likely that Clinton's *real* chance of winning is swinging so rapidly.  Similarly, when Brexit prediction markets assigned a 13% chance of Brexit a day before the event, they were clearly vastly underestimating the real propensity of Britain to secede from the European Union.

On the **subjective** view, saying that Hillary has an 80% chance of winning the election summarizes our *knowledge about* the election or our *state of uncertainty.*  It makes sense for the prediction market prices to change in response to new polls, because our current state of knowledge is changing.  If when prediction markets say 60%, the corresponding event happens around 6 times out of 10, that's a well-calibrated prediction market. When prediction markets say 13%, the corresponding event needs to happen *sometimes* (like 2 in 15 times) because if it didn't, the prediction market would be underconfident and you could systematically make money by selling the long-shots.

On the **frequentist** view, we cannot formally or rigorously say anything about the 2016 presidential election, because it only happens once.  We can't *observe* a frequency with which Clinton wins presidential elections.  A non-straw frequentist might concede that they would, indeed, cheerfully buy for \$1 a ticket that pays \$20 if Clinton wins, considering this an extremely favorable bet... in an *informal* sense, using a kind of reasoning that isn't based in rigorous epistemology, and might not be all that coherent, and certainly isn't suitable for being included in science journals.

## A coin with an unknown bias

Suppose we have a coin, weighted so that it lands heads somewhere between 0% and 100% of the time, but we don't know the coin's actual bias.

The coin is then flipped three times where we can see it.  It comes up heads twice, and tails once:  HHT.

The coin is then flipped again, where nobody can see it yet.  An honest and trustworthy experimenter lets you spin a wheel-of-gambling-odds, and the wheel lands on (2 : 1).  The experiment asks if you'd enter into a gamble where you win \$2 if the unseen coinflip is tails, and pay \$1 if the unseen coinflip is heads.

(The reason for spinning the wheel-of-gambling-odds is to reduce the worry that the experimenter might know more about the coin than you, and be offering you a deliberately rigged bet.)

On a **propensity** view, the coin has some objective probability between 0 and 1 of being heads, but we don't know this probability.  Seeing HHT tells us that the coin isn't all-heads or all-tails, but we're still just guessing what the real propensity is - we don't really know the answer.

On a **frequentist** view, the coin would produce some long-run frequency $f$ of heads that is between 0 and 1.  In other words, if we keep flipping the coin long enough, the actual proportion $p$ of observed heads is guaranteed to approach $f$ arbitrarily closely, eventually.  This is a true statement about the class of events where we continue to flip the coin - we can't say that the *next* coinflip is guaranteed to be H or T, but we can make a true statement about $p$ approaching $f$ to within epsilon if we continue to flip the coin long enough.

So what does a frequentist do with the data HHT?  A frequentist might try to apply an "unbiased estimator" to the data we have so far.  An "unbiased estimator" is a rule for making an estimate $e$ of $f$ based on observations, such that if we start by thinking about the true value of $f,$ applying this rule to data randomly generated from $f,$ produces an estimate $e$ whose expectation is $f.$  In other words, a frequentist wants a rule such that, if the hidden bias of the coin was in fact to yield 75% heads, and we repeat many times the operation of flipping the coin a few times and then asking a new frequentist to estimate the coin's bias using this rule, the *average* value of the estimated bias will be 0.75.  This is a true and rigorous statement about the estimation rule.  We can't hope for a rule that will always, in any particular case, yield the true $f$ from just a few coinflips; but we can have a rule of which we can rigorously say that the *average* estimate it yields, if we repeat this experiment many times, is $f.$

In this case, a simple unbiased estimator is to guess that the coin's bias $f$ is equal to the observed proportion $p$ of heads, or 2/3.  This means that a bet of \$2 vs. $\1 is fair, meaning that it doesn't yield an expected profit, so we have no reason to take the bet.

On a **Bayesian** view, we start out psychologically unsure of where the bias $f$ lies within the interval [0, 1].  Unless we have any knowledge or suspicion leading us to think otherwise, the coin is equally liable to have a bias between 31% and 32%, as to have a bias between 60% and 61%.

Each coinflip we see is then [22x evidence] about the value of $f,$ since a flip H happens with different probabilities depending on the different values of $f,$ and we update our beliefs about $f$ using [1lz Bayes's Rule].

E.g., we start out thinking the coin is equally likely to have a bias in the range $[\frac{1}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{1}{3} + \epsilon]$ as in $[\frac{2}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{2}{3} + \epsilon].$  We then observe one coinflip which comes up H.  Seeing H is twice is likely if $f=\frac{2}{3}$ than if $f=\frac{1}{3}$ so by [1zm Bayes's Rule] we should now think $f$ is twice as likely to lie in the interval $[\frac{2}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{2}{3} + \epsilon]$ as in $[\frac{1}{3} - \epsilon, \frac{1}{3} + \epsilon]$.

When we start with a uniform [219 prior], observe multiple flips of a coin with an unknown bias, see M heads and N tails, and then try to estimate the odds of the next flip coming up heads, the result is [21c Laplace's Rule of Succession] which estimates (M + 1) : (N + 1) or a probability of $\frac{M + 1}{M + N + 2}.$

In this case, after observing HHT, we estimate odds of 2/5 vs. 3/5 for tails vs. heads on the next flip.  This makes a gamble that wins \$2 on tails and loses \$1 on heads a profitable gamble in expectation, so we take the bet.

Our choice of a [219 uniform prior] over $f$ was *somewhat* shaky - it expressed ignorance in an obvious way, but obviousness isn't everything.  However, all the reasoning we did past that point was rigorous and based on [1bv probability theory], which various [coherence_theorems coherence theorems] prove to be the only way of manipulating quantified uncertainty that obeys obvious-seeming rules about how subjective uncertainty should behave.  Given our starting beliefs and quantified uncertainties, the remaining reasoning steps we carried out were *valid,* the way that $((X \rightarrow Y) \wedge (Y \rightarrow Z))\rightarrow(X \rightarrow Z)$ is valid reasoning in propositional logic.  [4xx There's no reason not to include this kind of reasoning in a science paper.]

## Probability that the 98,765th decimal digit of $\pi$ is $0$.

The **propensity** and **frequentist** views regard as nonsense the notion that we could talk about the *probability* of a mathematical fact.  Either the 98,765th decimal digit of $\pi$ is $0$ or it's not.  If we're running *repeated* experiments with a random number generator, then it might make sense to say that the random number generator has a 1\10 probability of picking numbers whose corresponding decimal digit of $\pi$ is $0$.  But if we're just picking a non-random number like 98,765, there's no sense in which we could say that the 98,765th digit of $\pi$ has a 10% propensity to be $0$, or that this digit is $0$ with 10% frequency in the long run.

The **subjectivist** considers probabilities to just refer to their own uncertainty.  So if a Bayesian has picked the number 98,765 without yet knowing the corresponding digit of $\pi,$ and hasn't made any observation that is known to them to be entangled with the 98,765th digit of $\pi,$ and they're pretty sure their friend hasn't yet looked up the 98,765th digit of $\pi$ either, and their friend offers a whimsical gamble that costs \$1 if the digit is $1-9$ and pays \$20 if the digit is $0,$ the Bayesian takes the bet.

*(Note:  You should no longer take this exact bet because somebody is going to look it up after reading this node, and if they offer you that exact bet, it might be because the number they looked up was not $0$.  Pick a different digit of $\pi$ instead.)*

# Generality of subjectivism

Subjective probabilities embrace all frequentist and propensity-based statements as special cases.

If it's a fact about a coin-flipping machine that its physical symmetries are such as to produce 50% heads in a way that's impossible for us to predict in any greater detail, then all the valid reasoning steps within the propensity view of probability will also be valid reasoning steps within the subjectivist view of probability.  E.g. a subjectivist agrees that if you roll two standard six-sided dice and add the results, the subjective probability of seeing 7 is 1/6.

Similarly, a Bayesian will agree that the estimation rule M/(M+N) for the probability $p$ of the next coin being heads, based on seeing M heads and N tails, has the property that its expected estimate equals the true frequency... or rather, the Bayesian thinks this in advance of actually running the experiment.  As soon as the coin actually comes up HHT, the Bayesian thinks that 2/3 is not actually a good estimate of the chance that the next coin will be heads.  In other words, the Bayesian disagrees that the 'unbiased estimator' property means you get reasonable answers when you actually run the rule on any particular occasion.  But the Bayesian does agree that the 'unbiased estimator' property being asserted, is subjectively valid, given their current uncertainty about the coin and the future experimental results.

# Arguments

As near as the author of this node can figure, the philosophical case *against* subjectivism (or *for* frequentism or propensity-based views) rests on a charge of epistemological sloppiness, with the implication that some other view of probability is more firmly grounded.  The Bayesian reply is something along the lines of "Mathematically rigorous probability theory!  Coherence theorems showing this theory is unique!  We're continuing to improve the theory of priors, and if you don't implicitly assume something along the lines of 'induction works' then your own reasoning wouldn't work either.  And your alternative view of probability [4xx leads to weird practices] because of arbitrarily excluding perfectly valid lines of reasoning."

For more, see [4xx here] or the [SEP entry on interpretations of probability](http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/probability-interpret/).
